INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY 
DEPARTMENT 
MISSION STATEMENT 
Promote operational efficiencies and employee productivity through high quality Information 
Technology (IT) services and innovative products in alignment with the community’s vision. 
BUDGET OVERVIEW 
Employee wages and benefits represent 70% of total IT Department expenditures and typically 
account for the largest cost. The Department has unified several groups into a centralized IT 
Department. This includes adding 3.0 FTE from other departments, centralizing the deployment 
and management of print services (MPS), and centralizing both mobile and enterprise telephony 
services. Geographic Information System (GIS) has also moved into the IT Department to better 
leverage mapping services throughout the City. Overhead costs such as materials and supplies, 
internal service charges, licensing, and training to maintain professional knowledge in a rapidly 
changing IT industry constitute the remainder of the budget.

POLICE DEPARTMENT  
SPECIAL PROJECTS 
In FY 17-18, the Police Department will have the following one-time, pilot, or special projects to: 
 The Police Department, Corvallis Regional Communications Center and the Corvallis Fire 
Department are evaluating movement to a regional Records Management System, Computer 
Aided Dispatch and Mobile software application in conjunction with mid-Willamette valley 
public safety agencies. This collaboration would bring regional public safety onto the same 
operating platforms and create regional interoperability, improving effectiveness. 
Anticipated cost would be $315,000, budgeted in Special Projects, plus $211,050 for Police 
and Dispatcher training which will all have to be done on overtime. Funding for this project 
will come from remaining special project funding in FY 16-17 and anticipated savings from 
Personal Services totaling $401,050 from the Corvallis Police Department and $125,000 from 
Fire Department FY 16-17 savings. 
 The City received a multi-year federally funded bulletproof vest grant in 2016. Replacement 
vests for current officers and vests for new hires are being purchased as needed; however, 
final expenditure and reimbursement for this grant funding will not occur until FY 17-18.  
$3,780 will be carried forward to be fully expended in FY 17-18 if federal funding remains 
available. 
 The Law Enforcement Building is managed through an intergovernmental agreement with 
Benton County Facilities. In FY 17-18 there are two facility projects scheduled for a total cost 
of $13,750 to the City.  
 One special project for $10,000 is planned for FY 17-18 in the 9-1-1 Fund to replace the 
Computer Aided Dispatch computers in the Dispatch Center. These computers are in use 24/7 
and must be replaced at least every five years. Additionally, these current CAD computers 
must be upgraded immediately to mitigate the computers freezing due to the ProQA software 
demand.  
 One detective vehicle and three marked patrol vehicles will be replaced in FY 17-18 from the 
vehicle reserve fund for $167,890, in accordance with the replacement schedule.   
 One purchase from Reserves in the 9-1-1 Fund is planned in FY 17-18. The 9-1-1 
communications system includes base stations and repeaters at Prairie Peak, Logsdon Ridge, 
Wren, Monroe, Law Enforcement Building and Public Works. These base stations/repeaters 
are on the Reserve Equipment Replacement Schedule over the next five years with the first 
replacement scheduled in FY 17-18 at a cost of $36,500.

BUDGET SUMMARY 
The department’s over-arching budget priority is to deliver community-policing services which 
means having an institutionalized philosophy that guides the delivery of police services by 
forming a partnership between the police and the community to “co-produce” public safety. 
The Police Department will contribute $150,000 to the Vehicle/Equipment Reserve Fund. 
The vehicle replacement plan currently has no replacements for two patrol vehicles.  If these 
vehicles were placed on the schedule, an additional $100,000 would need to be contributed to 
reserves to maintain reserve fund viability. 
 
The 9-1-1 Fund budget for FY 17-18 includes funding for the 17th dispatcher position, which has 
remained authorized but unfunded since FY 14-15.  With the additional workload from 
implementation of the ProQA Fire/EMS dispatching software and NextGen Text to 9-1-1, it is no 
longer sustainable to keep this authorized FTE vacant.  
 
Funding the 9-1-1 Center at levels commensurate with user agency and community expectations 
is a fine balance between the increasing costs of necessary technology, infrastructure, staffing 
and operations, versus the limited general fund resources available to user agencies.  The current 
funding model of CRCC is based on a 1983 Intergovernmental Agreement between the user 
agencies.  Due to increasing community service requirements and technological advances in the 
emergency communications systems statewide, this funding model is no longer viable to sustain 
ongoing operations.  Contracting the 9-1-1 services out would cost more than current operations, 
based on the narrow margin in which the 9-1-1 Fund currently operates.  The User Board is 
committed to an equitable funding concept countywide as proposed in the Emergency Services 
Consulting, Inc. district feasibility study of 2012, and hopes to work toward such a model during 
the FY 17-18 budget cycle, and as part of the Sustainable Budget Task Force work.

INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY 
DEPARTMENT 
MISSION STATEMENT 
Promote operational efficiencies and employee productivity through high quality Information 
Technology (IT) services and innovative products in alignment with the community’s vision. 
BUDGET OVERVIEW 
Employee wages and benefits represent 70% of total IT Department expenditures and typically 
account for the largest cost. The Department has unified several groups into a centralized IT 
Department. This includes adding 3.0 FTE from other departments, centralizing the deployment 
and management of print services (MPS), and centralizing both mobile and enterprise telephony 
services. Geographic Information System (GIS) has also moved into the IT Department to better 
leverage mapping services throughout the City. Overhead costs such as materials and supplies, 
internal service charges, licensing, and training to maintain professional knowledge in a rapidly 
changing IT industry constitute the remainder of the budget.

FIRE DEPARTMENT  
SPECIAL PROJECTS 
National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) 1851 sets standards related to the maintenance of 
personal protective equipment (PPE), which includes structural turnout gear.  The standard 
defines acceptable condition of the PPE and when it must be retired.  These guidelines help 
dictate the department’s turnout replacement schedule; however, replacements have been 
continually deferred in order to help meet budget constraints for multiple years now.  In an effort 
to work toward achieving the national standard, the department was able to replace 13 sets with 
one-time General Fund monies granted by the City Manager in FY 16-17.  In FY 17-18, City Council 
granted another $10,000 to go toward this effort, which should pay for roughly three more sets 
of turnouts.

FIRE DEPARTMENT 
MISSION STATEMENT 
To protect the lives, safety, property, and environment of all persons in the community and 
surrounding areas we serve; to educate, inform, and enforce life safety with knowledge and 
fairness to give the fullest measure of service for the cost. 
 
BUDGET OVERVIEW 
The Corvallis Fire Department (CFD) has three high priority areas of focus: Prevention, 
Readiness, and Response. The FY 17-18 Adopted Budget does not provide the capacity to offer 
any new programs or services. The department is able to fund all authorized positions while still 
within assigned budget restraints, but that does not account for any unforeseen events that may 
affect the budget as adopted. As in prior years, the department may be faced with defunding any 
vacant positions in the new fiscal year in order to accommodate any significant expenditure 
increases.

HUMAN RESOURCES DEPARTMENT 
MISSION STATEMENT 
Human Resources is dedicated to collaborating with City departments to recruit, develop, and 
retain a highly skilled workforce that is committed to excellence in public service. The Human 
Resources Team strives to deliver quality customer service and be a professional resource for 
managers and employees. Providing quality human resource support increases employee 
efficiency and effectiveness and reduces risks and costs associated with personnel management. 
The Central Administrative Services Division (CAS) supports the administrative functions for 
departments in City Hall and surrounding locations.  
BUDGET OVERVIEW 
Employee wages and benefits represent the largest cost at more than 49% of total HR 
expenditures for FY 17-18. Other costs such as labor legal fees and supplies, which includes paper 
for the document-intensive work of human resources and central administration in the public 
sector, constitutes much of the remaining budget expenditures.

BUDGET SUMMARY 
The FY 17-18 IT budget includes a number of major changes for both the Department and the 
City as a whole. The most significant change to the budget is in staffing. Three full time technical 
positions, previously in other departments, have been absorbed by the IT Department as part of 
an ongoing effort to streamline and centralize IT services. In addition, some roles have been 
converted to provide a more robust and effective Department. A Project Manager and Operations 
Supervisor have been created to replace vacant positions, and provide additional services. The 
GIS group, which includes 1.0 FTE, an intern, and several contracts, have moved from Public 
Works into the IT Department. IT now coordinates print services, including printing costs and 
contract costs that are charged back to user departments through ISCs. This allows for centralized 
management and contract negotiations of all printers and copiers throughout the City. The final 
major budget change is the inclusion of the Government Access Channel 21 TV station 
maintenance into the Department. These changes will help increase the overall efficiency of the 
City's technology systems and services.

BUDGET SUMMARY 
Overhead costs such as utilities, insurance premiums, merchant card and bank fees, materials 
and supplies such as paper for the document-intensive work of the department, and training to 
maintain professional knowledge in a highly regulated financial management industry represent 
a significant cost at 48% of total Finance Department expenditures, while employee wages 
represent the largest cost at 52%. Insurance rates and bank transaction fees from credit card use 
continue to increase significantly each year.  
The Finance Department operates in the General and Parking Funds for Municipal Court, the 
Administrative Services Fund for Financial and Customer Services, and the Risk Management 
Fund for property and liability insurance premiums for the City.

INTRODUCTION 
This section of the budget provides an overview of the organization’s total budget. It includes 
tables and graphs to provide different views of the data across the entire budget, and includes an 
overview of revenue and expense factors that impact all operations; issues that are unique to a 
specific fund are discussed with the fund’s financial plan, immediately following the overview.  
BUDGET OVERVIEW 
The City’s total budget for FY 17-18 is balanced in each fund, where revenues, combined with 
reserves or fund balance, equal or exceed planned expenditures. All revenues are expected to 
total $120,864,790, a 1.53% increase over the adopted budget for FY 16-17. All expenditures are 
projected to total $130,160,810, a 0.18% decrease from the adopted budget for FY 16-17.  
Operating revenues are projected to increase 1.75% or $1.9 million over the FY 16-17 adopted 
budget. Operating expenses, the primary focus of the budget process, are projected to be 0.86% 
or $842,610 below the FY 16-17 adopted budget.

FINANCE DEPARTMENT 
MISSION STATEMENT 
Corvallis Municipal Court is committed to serving all citizens in a courteous, efficient and 
professional manner, and providing each person accused of a violation, infraction or crime a fair 
and timely resolution consistent with due process and equality under the law.   
Financial Services facilitates informed decision making for the City Council and the organization 
to improve the City’s financial strength and viability for current and future generations, and to 
provide optimal financial services to a wide range of constituents including the City Council, 
community members, taxpayers, businesses, agencies and employees of the City. Finance 
Department staff is committed to best practices that provide for timely, accurate, clear and 
complete information, and ensures that the City’s financial resources are collected, protected, 
invested and distributed in a fiscally responsible manner.

FIRE & RESCUE SERVICES 
Major Projects for FY 17-18: 
 The Fire Department will research replacement of its records management system (RMS) as 
a result of the City moving to a new CAD system. 
All Fire Department personnel costs are accounted for within Fire & Rescue Services, as the 
department has determined that an employee’s time cannot be accurately split among 
Prevention, Readiness and Response activities. When not responding to an emergency, staff are 
performing other essential tasks including maintenance on buildings and fire apparatus, 
managing programs in their respective assigned areas, or public education outreach or attending 
training, both of which are vital to mitigating potential emergencies and being readily prepared 
for them as they arise.

C i t y  o f  C o r v a l l i s  –  F Y  1 7 - 1 8  A d o p t e d  B u d g e t  
Page 92 
The Planning Division is supported primarily by the General Fund, but receives additional 
funding for a dedicated long range planning position from the voter-approved 2013 five-year 
Operating Levy, as well as a small grant from the State Historic Preservation Office (SHPO). 
Planning Division revenues come from three sources and are projected as follows for FY 17-18: 
the five-year Operating Levy ($165,680), land use application fees ($143,330), and annual grants 
from SHPO ($8,000) ($3,000 is revenue allocated in FY 16-17 and reimbursed in FY 17-18). 
Revenues from land use application fees have fluctuated significantly in past years, and are 
difficult to predict for upcoming years. SHPO grant dollars must be used for historic preservation-
related work. Per State law, land use application fees may not exceed the “actual or average cost” 
of processing land use applications. 
The Housing and Neighborhood Services Division operates in the Community Development 
Revolving Fund, in which federal Community Development Block Grant and HOME Investment 
Partnerships program funds are received. Those resources are expended to support low-income 
affordable housing, community development and social service activities. The CD Revolving Fund 
also houses the budget for the City’s Rental Housing Program, which provides education, 
information and referral services for rental property owners, tenants, and community members.  
New revenue generation from an Affordable Housing Construction Excise Tax began in FY 16-17; 
those revenues will continue in FY 17-18 and will support affordable housing planning, programs 
and projects during the second half of FY 17-18.

VEHICLE/EQUIPMENT RESERVE FUND 
The Vehicle/Equipment Reserve Fund is used to hold monies set-aside year-to-year for future 
year equipment replacement.  
Revenues 
Revenues are generally from interfund transfers from the General or other Special Revenue 
Funds. A small amount of revenue is projected each year for interest earnings based on the 
balances held in the fund. 
Expenses 
Expenses are all considered to be special projects – one-time in nature. The most common use of 
these funds is to replace vehicles as they age. Depending on the type of vehicle, costs can be 
substantial (e.g., Fire Department ladder truck), and though many of the most expensive vehicles 
have a relatively long expected-useful-life, the costs for replacement would be higher than could 
be absorbed within the Department’s regular budget. 
Another significant type of project budgeted in this fund is the acquisition of a new or 
replacement technology system. For FY 16-17 through FY 18-19, the City will be replacing the 
current Finance, Municipal Court, and Utility Billing information systems and implementing its 
first Human Resources Information System. In addition, the Police and Fire Departments are in 
the planning stage to replace the Computer Aided Dispatch/Records Management System those 
two departments share. 
Finally, this fund holds reserves to begin to address the backlog of deferred maintenance projects 
at City facilities. In FY 17-18, $88,500 will be transferred to the Capital Construction Fund to 
complete the project initiated in FY 16-17 to repair and re-point the bricks on City Hall.  
Opportunities/Challenges 
With the initiation of the facility reserves, the City is moving toward centralized management of 
the facilities used for operations and public functions. This should allow for better long-term 
planning for maintenance projects. Staff also recognizes that setting monies aside for facilities 
reduces monies available for programs, but addressing deferred maintenance is critical to ensure 
the health and safety of staff and community members.

Page 29 
Charges for service in the internal service funds (Fleet Maintenance, Facility Maintenance, 
Technology and Communications, Administrative Services, and Risk Management), where the 
service is provided by one City department to other City departments, are established based on 
covering the projected costs for each service area. Costs are then allocated to operating 
departments using drivers specific to the service area. Internal service charges are generally 
projected to increase slightly more than 4%. For FY 17-18 IT costs increased due to consolidation 
of IT and GIS staff resulting in an overall increase of 25%. The Fleet Maintenance Fund has a 17% 
increase over FY 16-17 due to some personnel changes. The Risk Management Fund is expecting 
a 17% increase due to a 9% increase in some liability premiums as well as needing to backfill 
approximately $128,500 higher than average workers compensations claims that were paid from 
contingencies in FY 16-17.  
Intergovernmental 
Regular sources of intergovernmental revenue are projected to continue in line with prior years, 
but some of the one-time grants that may occur during FY 17-18 are not currently anticipated. In 
addition, several years of Community Development Block Grants (CDBG) and HOME grants for 
affordable housing projects were expended in FY 16-17, leading to FY 17-18 anticipating only 
one year’s worth of grant receipts.  
Miscellaneous 
Miscellaneous revenue in FY 16-17 anticipated logging operations at both Chip Ross Park and at 
the Watershed. Only a small harvest is expected in FY 17-18 at the Watershed, leading to lower 
total miscellaneous revenues. Miscellaneous revenue also includes interest earnings in all funds 
as well as grants and donations from non-government entities. Interest earnings are projected to 
increase slightly in FY 17-18; donations are usually appropriated as they are made. 
EXPENSES 
Total operating expenses are expected to be 0.86% or $842,610 lower in FY 17-18 than in FY 16-
17. This reflects significant effort on the part of staff to hold the line on cost increases and meet 
the City Manager’s challenge to reduce costs by $1 million.  
Compensation 
Cities are service organizations; making compensation one of the largest expenditures each 
year. In FY 17-18, there are several factors driving compensation costs up: 
Cost-of-Living Adjustments (COLAs) 
The City has four bargaining units, plus the group of exempt employees. The bargaining units 
have collective bargaining agreements (CBA) negotiated within the State legal requirements 
of the Public Employee Collective Bargaining Act (PECBA). Each CBA specifies the COLA to 
be budgeted each year, as follows: 
 American Federation of State, County, and Municipal Employees (AFSCME) – this is the 
unit for the majority of the City’s general service employees. The current CBA expires June 
30, 2018, and calls for a 2.0% COLA effective June 16, 2017.

BUDGET SUMMARY 
Employee wages and benefits represent the largest cost at 64% of total Parks and Recreation 
Department expenditures. Materials and Services such as utilities and contractors comprise the 
balance of the budget. The Aquatic Center largely operates through the Local Option Levy 
($519,640), charges for service, grants and donations ($989,710) and the General Fund 
($161,910). The Senior Center largely operates through the Local Option Levy ($388,660), 
charges for service, grants and donations ($149,000) and the General Fund ($41,270). The 
Majestic Theatre is budgeted in Special Projects as is currently a pilot venture.

PUBLIC WORKS DEPARTMENT 
SPECIAL PROJECTS 
Special projects are one-time, or infrequent, work efforts that are budgeted and tracked 
separately from departments operating expenditures. Many of the special projects are for 
the purchase of asset replacements, such as vehicles or pumps, or for periodic maintenance, 
such as exterior painting of public buildings. Segmenting these one-time projects provides 
for a more accurate picture in the operating budget of what it takes on an annual basis to 
support operations.

Technology and Communications – to account for revenue and expenses associated with 
operating the City of Corvallis' central computer, GIS, and telephone systems. The major source of 
revenue is charges for service paid by operating departments based on a cost allocation plan. 
Expenses are for maintenance of the data center facility and equipment, information systems,

any accrued balance each year returned proportionately to the contributing funds or held as a 
reserve for future capital.

The change in methodology to move Special Projects from the above table makes it difficult to

e final year for outstanding voter-approved General 
Obligation debt. 
See page 228 for more detail. 
Interfund transfers move monies between funds for a variety of purposes. All funds contribute to 
the Pension Obligation Debt Service fund to pay each year’s POB debt; the transfer is proportional 
to each fund’s prior year costs for PERS contributions. Other transfers occur each year to move 
current revenues to fund capital projects. 
See page 236 for more detail. 
Other non-operating uses reflects the pass-throughs the City is required to collect on behalf of 
other government organizations. The expense is offset dollar-for-dollar by non-operating 
revenues. The amounts vary each year, often most affected by the level of development in the 
community. 
Contingencies are budgeted in each fund. In the General Fund, the contingency budget is set at 
10% of the Fund Balance Reserve. In all other funds, the contingency is set at 2% of revenue 
unless there is a mitigating concern that would cause the contingency to be higher. Contingencies

C i t y  o f  C o r v a l l i s  –  F Y  1 7 - 1 8  A d o p t e d  B u d g e t  
Page 34 
are appropriated for emergencies and are rarely used. Council action is required to move the 
appropriation from the contingency classification to another department appropriation level, if 
needed. 
FUND BALANCE 
Each fund holds a fund balance that includes reserves for specific purposes, and balances 
available to spend. Each fund’s fund balance represents the accrual over time when revenues 
exceed expenditures. When one year’s balance is lower than the prior year, it reflects a use of the 
reserves. The fund balance is a good financial planning tool when monies are saved over several 
years to allow for a larger than usual one-time expense. The City sets aside reserves for large 
capital projects, vehicle and technology system replacements, future year’s PERS payment 
increases, and facility maintenance.  
The Fund Balance is also a useful tool to provide cash flow, particularly in the general fund, where 
property tax revenue is not received until November each year.

C i t y  o f  C o r v a l l i s  –  F Y  1 7 - 1 8  A d o p t e d  B u d g e t  
Page 124 
Revenue Highlights: 
 The 2013 Operating Levy provides funding for an additional 1.0 FTE Fire Prevention Officer. 
 The second year of the Corvallis Rural Fire Protection District (CRFPD) contract brings the 
District’s remittance rate to the City up to 81% of tax revenues collected by the District, which 
estimates to be an additional $15,460. 
 Ambulance Services revenues are expected to again moderately increase as a result of 
increased calls for service, an approved ambulance service rate schedule increase to take 
effect July 1, 2017, and successful collection efforts, despite offsetting reductions in 
Medicare/Medicaid reimbursements and mandatory write-offs.   
Expenditure Highlights: 
 Vacancies and minor staffing reorganization created Personnel Services savings in FY 16-17 
that were repurposed for spending in FY 16-17, and in some cases, carried over to FY 17-18 
for: deferred facility maintenance, a contract continuation for EMS ProQA priority dispatch 
system call review, as well as financial support to the Vehicle/Equipment Reserve Fund for 
the replacement of the Computer-Aided Dispatch/Records Management System (CAD/RMS). 
 Contractual cost-of-living adjustments and five planned retirements contribute to the 
increase seen in FY 17-18 Personnel Services. 
 FY 17-18 Materials and Services include over $130,500 in carry-overs referenced above, and 
over $200,000 in Internal Service Charge increases. 
 Capital Outlay’s volatile history includes replacement of fire apparatus and large equipment; 
replacements will be separately approved in future year special projects.

C i t y  o f  C o r v a l l i s  –  F Y  1 7 - 1 8  A d o p t e d  B u d g e t  
Page 17 
 Lead paint remediation for the Avery Park restroom exterior ($4,000) and Sunnyside 
School exterior ($20,000). These two one-time projects are needed for the safety of 
community members and staff who are in and around the facilities. 
 Pilot project funding for a crew of casual Parks & Recreation employees for illegal camp 
clean-up for $15,000. This is a new approach to illegal camp clean-up, using a crew that 
is expected to work year-round to more proactively address the environmental impact of 
illegal camps in the park system. 
These and other changes will require on-going assessments of the effectiveness of the 
organization. When needed, plans will be modified and changes implemented to ensure 
community objectives are being met. 
The Proposed Budget was also developed recognizing the number of community groups who 
appeared before the Mayor and City Council seeking grants for their operations. As a result, the 
Proposed Budget includes $135,630 in recurring General Fund revenue that has not been 
allocated and is available to use to fund staff requested service improvements or to allocate as 
grants to community groups.  
SUMMARY OF BUDGET CHANGES 
This Proposed Budget continues to implement changes started in FY 16-17 to make the budget 
and budget process more transparent. This includes: 
 Developing a new Mayor and City Council budget section to provide the community with 
better information about the costs for governance, including hard costs for the work 
Advisory Boards and Commissions complete each year, and the grants the City Council 
provides to community groups.  
 Separating the special projects budgets into their own appropriation category. Special 
Projects are defined as those tasks that are one-time, and often use one-time revenue such 
as a grant to fund the work. Staff expects that this change will allow the community to 
better understand some significant variances in total spending each year by being able to 
see the impact of these projects. It will also more clearly communicate the on-going 
operating cost for departments. 
 Increasing the information in each department’s budget pages to include division-level 
information about the services each division is responsible for and an organization chart 
for each division.  
 Tightening the materials and services budgets to decrease individual line cost estimates 
in favor of building in a “lump sum” internal contingency. If actual costs are higher than 
expected, the internal contingency can be drawn on if costs exceed the new, lower 
baseline budget. This mechanism is intended to help increase accuracy of budgeting into 
the future, as well as provide staff with the flexibility to manage unexpected cost 
increases without eliminating planned service or project delivery. 
 The 9-1-1 Fund has adequate resources projected to fill the 17th Dispatch position that 
has been unfunded for the last four years.

MISSION STATEMENT 
Enrich, Excite, Explore 
The Corvallis-Benton County Public Library will be an inspiring and vital part of the lives of 
people of all ages and backgrounds in our communities. We will: 
 Be responsive, flexible and innovative in providing resources and services that enhance the 
quality of life for all; 
 Foster an impassioned spirit of exploration and discovery; 
 Strengthen our sense of community by encouraging civic and cultural engagement; 
 Support learning and knowledge.

Mission 
Provide fiscal management, financial reporting, administer treasury services, and provide grant 
accounting information to City Management and elected officials so they can make informed decisions 
regarding the provision of City services. 
FY 2019 Key Results 
•
Investment Earnings – FY19 4th Qtr - $10,958,817
•
Completed FY18 audit with zero findings for the 3rd consecutive year
FY 2020 Budget 
FY 2020 Key Deliverables 
•
Complete the FY19 audit with no financial findings
•
Implement GASB Statement No. 84, Fiduciary Activities
•
Begin implementation of GASB Statement No. 87, Leases
Key Functions: 
Responsible for all cash disbursement 
Facilitate payment to vendors through a decentralized 
accounts payable process 
Manage City’s investments in accordance with state 
law and City Ordinances 
Administer grants

Mission 
Committed to providing professional development services for Urban Planning, Building Permitting and 
Building Inspections to the City of El Paso Departments and the Public so they can sustain and enjoy one 
of America’s most livable cities.
Key Functions: 
Develop current and long range planning services to 
help shape the physical development of the City 
Consolidation of permitting and inspection services at 
the One-Stop-Shop (OSS) to create a more efficient 
development process for the community 
FY 2019 Key Results 
•
119 new commercial permits issued (excluding trade permits) with a valuation of $354M, 32%
increase over FY18
•
48,208 Customers Assisted in under 7 minutes 96% of customers rated service provide as very
satisfied or satisfied
FY 2020 Budget 
FY 2020 Key Deliverables 
•
Amend Title 20 to streamline zoning application approval, Amend Title 21 to allow for better
application of SmartCode regulations
•
Lean Six Sigma project on permitting and inspections process
•
Assignment of inspectors to projects from beginning–to-end to provide consistent inspections and
follow-up

Materials and Supplies  
This 
category 
includes 
costs 
of 
expendable items used by operating 
activities. Supplies and material costs 
increased 7.3% from $53.4 million in 
FY 2019 to $57.4 million in FY 2020. 
The variance is primarily due to a 
facility renovations through the Capital 
Improvement Department and for QoL 
projects coming online at Parks and 
Recreation. General Fund Materials 
and Supplies for FY 2020 are budgeted 
at $21.1 million, which accounts for 
36.8% of the total Material and 
Supplies All Fund’s budget.  
Operating Expenditures 
This category includes items that support 
day-to-day operations of a department 
such 
as 
utilities, 
mileage 
reimbursements, 
travel, 
training 
expenses, and communication costs. 
Also 
included 
are 
indirect 
cost 
expenditures budgeted by enterprise 
funds to cover their share of overhead 
costs in the General Fund. The city does 
not budget for depreciation expense, 
which explains the large variance from 
actuals to adopted in this category.  The 
total budget for Operating Expenditures 
stayed relatively flat from FY 2019 to FY 
2020. Approximately 48.7%, of costs in 
this category are budgeted in the 
General Fund.

CITY OF 
 EL PASO 
Financial Summaries
FY 2020 BUDGET 
Non-Operating Expenditures  
This category includes costs such as 
principal 
and 
interest 
expense, 
community service project allocations, 
housing 
rehabilitation 
costs, 
and 
damages/settlement 
costs 
and 
represents 13.8% of the total All 
Funds budget. The budget for FY 
2020 increased by 5.9% from $136.3 
million to $144.4 million predominately 
due 
to 
additional 
debt 
service 
payments 
for 
bonds. 
The 
City 
switched from a reimbursement model 
for debt to issuing debt prior to the 
construction of projects to take 
advantage of lower interest rates. A 
small percentage (1.3%) of the 
category is budgeted within the 
General Fund.
Intergovernmental Expenditures 
This 
category 
includes 
grant-
matching funds in order to leverage 
federal and state funding.  A change 
in method was implemented in FY 
2017.  The City continues to seek 
out grant opportunities and will 
provide necessary matching dollars 
but the grant dollars will now remain 
completely separated from match 
dollars. This change ensures better 
accounting practices and also stops 
the practice where the match dollars 
were spent “twice” on the city’s 
books.  The budget for FY 2020 
increased by 28.8% from $2.5 
million to $3.3 million primarily due 
to grant match for Mass Transit - 
Sun Metro.

Other Uses 
This 
category 
includes 
nonrecurring transfers that do 
not qualify as revenues or 
expenditures to the receiving or 
disbursing department.  Other 
Uses increased 16.6% from 
$92.8 million in FY 2019 to 
$108.2 million in FY 2020, due 
to transfers related to debt 
service for the Airport, and the 
increase to the Environmental 
Franchise 
Fee 
for 
street 
projects. Approximately 32.8% 
of this category is budgeted 
under the General Fund.  
Capital Outlay 
This category includes construction, 
equipment, 
and 
land 
acquisition. 
Capital costs for FY 2020 are expected 
to increase by 43.8% from $27.9 
million in FY 2019 to an estimated 
$40.2 million.  The budget includes 
funding 
for 
a 
dedicated 
Street 
Maintenance Fund and for public 
safety capital replacement for Police 
and Fire. The variance can also be 
attributed to capital expenditures for 
Environmental Services for vehicle 
replacement and closure of Phase 1 of 
the 
Greater 
El 
Paso 
Landfill. 
Approximately 4.8% of this category is 
budgeted under the General Fund.

Mission 
To provide law enforcement and community based policing services to the El Paso Community so they 
can enjoy an enhanced quality of life without the fear of crime. 
Key Functions: 
Maintain public order 
Investigate crimes 
Protect people & property 
FY 2019 Key Results 
•
Provided over 650 crime and safety presentations with 60,380 attendees
•
105 of 150 new EPPD vehicles have been delivered, estimated completion August, 2019
•
34 body cameras  have been issued for Crisis Intervention Team and DWI Task Force
FY 2020 Budget 
FY 2020 Key Deliverables 
•
Decrease part 1 crimes by 2% (Larceny, Assaults, Burglary, Vehicle Theft)
•
Reduce priority 1 response times by 5% FY19 time: 17min 42sec
•
Reduce pedestrian traffic fatalities by 20% FY19: 29 fatalities

Strategic Actions 
Goal 2:  Set the Standard for a Safe and Secure City 
Strategy 2.1     Maintain designation as one of the nation’s top safest cities 
Action 2.1.1 
Increase preventative proactive policing 
Action 2.1.2 
Expand outreach opportunities to improve police/community partnerships and 
enhance customer safety 
Strategy 2.2     Strengthen community involvement in resident safety 
Action 2.2.1 
Strengthen the community policing initiative at each Regional Command to 
address quality of life issues and community order concerns 
Action 2.2.2 
Provide educational and volunteer opportunities for disaster preparedness 
Strategy 2.3     Increase public safety operational efficiency 
Action 2.3.1 
Maintain a highly skilled police force 
Action 2.3.2 
Effectively respond to police calls for service 
Action 2.3.6 
Improve the efficiency and effectiveness of criminal investigations 
Action 2.3.7 
Implement technology and/or technology upgrades to improve work flow 
efficiencies 
Strategy 2.4 
Improve motorist safety and traffic management solutions 
Action 2.4.1 
Analyze and implement tactics to reduce accidents 
Strategy 2.8 
Implement effective code enforcement strategies to reduce nuisances, enhance visual 
appearance and improve overall health and safety 
Action 2.8.1 
Investigate all animal bite cases reported 
Action 2.8.2 
Enhance Health and Safety Program

Part 1 Offense crime rate
•
Percentage of part I crimes cleared

Percentage of property crimes cleared

Police Department survey results on investigations

Mission 
To provide equitable access for customers to justice, City Council meetings, governmental records, and 
election services to members of the El Paso Community so they can resolve their cases and participate in 
city government.  
Key Functions 
Process Class C misdemeanor violations, parking 
citations, red light camera hearings, alarm 
ordinance hearings, taxi permit hearings 
Provide administrative support to Municipal Court 
judges 
FY 2019 Key Results 
•
Re-configuration of the public safety counters at 810 Overland – 2 additional windows/ADA
compliant
•
Awards include: 2019 Most Innovative Program, Traffic Safety Initiatives Award
FY 2020 Budget 
FY 2020 Key Deliverables 
•
Replace all video and audio equipment in all courtrooms and bond offices
•
Add video parking ticket hearings availability at all bond offices, once hardware is replaced
•
Expand intern program working with UTEP. Throughout the past 3 years, the Court had 17
interns; 10 have been hired in their field of study
•
Offer option of obtaining GED, on-line high school classes through Library or other agencies for
community service credit

Mission 
Provide tax collection and disbursement services to taxpayers and taxing entities so they can each fulfill 
their civic responsibilities of funding and providing public services.   
Key Functions: 
Collect property taxes 
Provide property tax information to the public 
Distribute funds and reporting to taxing 
entities 
FY 2019 Key Results 
•
Conducted 9information sessions during November through January 2019 and collected property
tax payments
•
Tax Office Mobile Bank collected $1.8M and serving 780 taxpayers from January 29-31, 2019

FY 2020 Key Deliverables 
•
Tax Office mobile bank at CAD –expand service from 3 to 5 days (January 27 –31, 2020)
•
Implement State legislative changes

Mission 
The Mission of Human Resources Department is to provide recruitment, total compensation, risk 
management, and organizational development services to departments and their employees, so they can 
achieve strategic and operational results for the community.  
Key Functions: 
Provide Recruitment & Employee Relations 
Administer Training, Development, Benefits & 
Risk Management 
Payroll Administration 
FY 2019 Key Results 
•
Opened Shape It Up Gym
•
Increased Wellness Classes
•
Added Wellness Coordinator
FY 2020 Budget 
FY 2020 Key Deliverables 
•
Build a new City Gym at Municipal Services Center
•
Hold the 2nd Annual Health Fair
•
Provide ongoing department specific safety training
•
Increase driver training resulting in continued reduction of vehicle accidents

CITY OF 
 EL PASO 
Financial Summaries
FY 2020 BUDGET 
Personal Services 
This category includes costs related to employee compensation such as salaries, wages, taxes, and fringe
benefits.  All Funds Personal Services costs increased by 4.9% or from $439.3 million in FY 2019 to $460.7
million in FY 2020. The increase in salary costs is largely attributable to the approved contracts with the
Police and Fire unions, compensation increases for non-uniform personnel, and the creation of new
positions to meet rising service demands.
The 
Fire 
Department’s 
Personal
Services budget rose $4.3 million or 
4.1% to allow for a 2.75% Cost of
Living Adjustment and increased
Healthcare 
costs. 
The
Police
Department’s 
Personal 
Services 
budget rose $7.7 million or 5.8% due 
to an increase in uniformed personnel
compensation and additional officers.
The Police Department has two
academies scheduled to graduate
over 100 cadets during FY 2020, and
two more academies planned to start
in February and July, which are
expected 
to 
yield 
70 
additional 
officers. The FY 2020 budget includes
a mid-year compensation increase for
non-uniformed personnel who will
receive a 1.0% increase. Several departments added additional staff including Human Resources, Library,
Municipal Court, Parks and Recreation, Public Health, Streets and Maintenance, and Zoo. General Fund
Personal Services for FY 2020 are budgeted at $334.9 million and represent 72.7% of the total All Funds
Personal Services budget.
Contractual Services 
This category includes costs that are
derived from contractual agreements
for services. Contractual service costs
decreased by 2.0% from $185.4 million
in FY 2019 to $181.7 million in FY
2020.  The decrease in this category
can be attributed to savings in Human
Resources from contract extension
with healthcare provider and a shift in
enrollment to CDHP. The decrease is
also due to an operational shift at
Streets and Maintenance to perform
median maintenance in house as
opposed to on contract. General Fund
Contractual Services for FY 2020 are
budgeted 
at 
$35.9 
million 
and
represent 19.8% of the All Funds
Contractual Services budget.

CITY OF 
 EL PASO 
Financial Summaries
FY 2020 BUDGET 
vehicles used to provide services, city wide contracts, shared personnel, and specific agreements and/or 
policies. This group also includes the costs for issuing bonds including bond refunding, proceeds from the 
sale of land, and loan proceeds. These revenues are not included in the operating budget since they are 
developed through Capital Improvement Program and debt planning budgeting process. For comparison 
purposes, Capital Project and Indirect Cost Recovery are included in this group.  
SIF Revenues 
The City provides employee health and workers’ compensation benefits under its self-insurance programs. 
Employee health and workers’ compensation benefit liabilities are accrued in the Internal Service Funds 
based upon actuarially determined estimates of the aggregate liability for unpaid benefits. The city records 
all health and workers’ compensation claims liabilities, including an estimate for claims incurred but not 
reported. In addition, the City has a stop-loss policy for health claims. The City is subject to the State of 
Texas Employment Commission Act. Under this act, the city’s method for providing unemployment 
compensation is to reimburse the State of Texas (State) for claims paid by the State. Activity for certain 
self-insurance programs is recorded in the city’s Internal Service Self-Insurance Fund. Assets and 
obligations related to employee health benefits, workers’ compensation, and unemployment compensation 
are included in the Self-Insurance Fund. The City is self-insured for general liability (excluding the Mass 
Transit Department’s fleet of vehicles and liability insurance for the Airport). Expenditures for these liabilities 
are accounted for in the General Fund, which pays any liabilities incurred. Additionally, the city maintains 
insurance policies acquired from independent insurance carriers for property insurance, errors and 
omissions insurance, and auto liability insurance coverage for some of the City’s fleet of vehicles.

Financial Summaries
FY 2020 BUDGET 
Other Uses 
This 
category 
includes 
nonrecurring transfers that do 
not qualify as revenues or 
expenditures to the receiving or 
disbursing department.  Other 
Uses increased 16.6% from 
$92.8 million in FY 2019 to 
$108.2 million in FY 2020, due 
to transfers related to debt 
service for the Airport, and the 
increase to the Environmental 
Franchise 
Fee 
for 
street 
projects. Approximately 32.8% 
of this category is budgeted 
under the General Fund.  
Capital Outlay 
This category includes construction, 
equipment, 
and 
land 
acquisition. 
Capital costs for FY 2020 are expected 
to increase by 43.8% from $27.9 
million in FY 2019 to an estimated 
$40.2 million.  The budget includes 
funding 
for 
a 
dedicated 
Street 
Maintenance Fund and for public 
safety capital replacement for Police 
and Fire. The variance can also be 
attributed to capital expenditures for 
Environmental Services for vehicle 
replacement and closure of Phase 1 of 
the 
Greater 
El 
Paso 
Landfill. 
Approximately 4.8% of this category is 
budgeted under the General Fund.

Mission 
Committed to providing professional development services for Urban Planning, Building Permitting and 
Building Inspections to the City of El Paso Departments and the Public so they can sustain and enjoy one 
of America’s most livable cities.
Key Functions: 
Develop current and long range planning services to 
help shape the physical development of the City 
Consolidation of permitting and inspection services at 
the One-Stop-Shop (OSS) to create a more efficient 
development process for the community 
FY 2019 Key Results 
•
119 new commercial permits issued (excluding trade permits) with a valuation of $354M, 32%
increase over FY18
•
48,208 Customers Assisted in under 7 minutes 96% of customers rated service provide as very
satisfied or satisfied
FY 2020 Budget 
FY 2020 Key Deliverables 
•
Amend Title 20 to streamline zoning application approval, Amend Title 21 to allow for better
application of SmartCode regulations
•
Lean Six Sigma project on permitting and inspections process
•
Assignment of inspectors to projects from beginning–to-end to provide consistent inspections and
follow-up

The El Paso Police Department continues to focus on reducing crime to 
maintain the City's standing as one of the nation's top safest cities. In FY 
2019, Police department reduced Part 1 crime by 11 % as compared to FY 
2018. During this time, the Homicide Clearance Rate was 100% compared to 
the 61.2% national average as published by the Federal Bureau of 
Investigations (FBI). 
The FY 2019 - 2020 Adopted Budget includes funding for two police 
academies, collective bargaining impacts, as well as overtime increases and 
equipment. The net increase of 55 police officers next fiscal year will bring the 
total to 156 over the last four years.

City Manager's Office 
For the second consecutive year, the Fire department was recognized as 
having one of the Best 100 Fleets. The FY 2019 - 2020 Adopted Budget 
further continues our commitment to investing in public safety, by providing 
funding for Fire and 911 Communicator academies. Additionally, $2.7 million 
in dedicated funding was included for Fire department equipment and vehicles 
and $1.3 million for Police capital. 
Voters in 2012 approved $473 million in Quality of Life bond projects. As of 
August 2019, we will have completed over 100 
projects. The Alameda and Dyer Brio construction 
was finalized and will start revenue service in early 
August. These are the second and third Brio lines 
in operation. The completion of the North Hills 
Street lighting project provides needed illumination to this significant roadway 
Program were paved.

in Northeast El Paso. In FY 2019, 95 streets were 
resurfaced as part of the 2012 Program; 326 
streets out of 415. In addition, four major arterials 
were substantially completed along with 34 
residential streets from the Residential Paving 
To continue our commitment to have Safe and Beautiful Neighborhoods, City 
Council voted to call an election for a $413.1 million bond issuance for Public 
Safety facilities, including Police and Fire Department motor vehicles and 
equipment. The Police Department's portion of the total bond is $221.9 million, 
which is allocated for facilities to include an Eastside Command Center, Police 
Headquarters and other facilities, along with fleet replacement. The remainder 
$191.2 million will be allocated to the Fire Department for a new Fire

Mission 
Facilitate the procurement of goods and services in an open, fair, transparent, economically competitive, 
and respectful process with the goal of maximizing taxpayers’ dollars. Therein promoting and fostering a 
climate of good business relationships between our suppliers and the City.   
FY 2019 Key Results 
•
67% of Awarded Contracts and Purchase Orders were issued to local vendors
•
EP Marketplace issued 4,441 Purchase Orders which resulted in cost avoidance of $519,597
•
Achievement of Excellence in Procurement – of the 10 largest cities in Texas, City of El Paso is 1
of 3 to receive this award for the 5th consecutive year
FY 2020 Budget 
FY 2020 Key Deliverables 
•
City Accelerator Inclusive Procurement Cohort – development of Veteran, Woman and Minority
Business Enterprise strategy
•
Plan to receive 6th consecutive Achievement of Excellence in Procurement Award
•
Implement Purchasing Ticketing System – Pilot program with 5 participating departments
Key Functions: 
Monitor annual contracts 
Contract administration 
Develop bid specifications 
Issuing and approving purchase orders 
Facilitate the bidding and contract awarding process
